active_learning.discussion_prompt: Discuss the benefits and challenges of conducting threat modeling exclusively in the SDLC design phase versus shifting left into requirements or integrating across DevSecOps pipelines. Provide real-world examples from web applications.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Threat Modeling in Design Phase (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security And Risk Management > Security Policy Development > Policy Implementation and Integration > SDLC Integration > Threat Modeling in Design Phase). Use the provided scaffolding layers, learning objectives, active learning ideas, and research context to generate 25 high-quality flashcards. Context: Threat modeling is a proactive security practice in SDLC design phase to identify/mitigate threats early (secure-by-design). Key frameworks: STRIDE (Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, Elevation of Privilege), NIST SP 800-154 (data-centric DFD-based threat modeling for federal systems, systematic threat identification). Tools: DFDs, trust boundaries, DREAD/CVSS prioritization. Sources: NIST SP 800-154 (https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/Legacy/SP/nistspecialpublication800-154.pdf), Microsoft STRIDE (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/security/develop/threat-modeling-tool-threats), CMS Handbook (https://security.cms.gov/policy-guidance/threat-modeling-handbook), Lockheed Martin (https://www.lockheedmartin.com/content/dam/lockheed-martin/rms/documents/cyber/LM-White-Paper-Threat-Driven-Approach.pdf), OWASP Threat Modeling, PASTA. Incorporate: Prior knowledge (SDLC, risk assessment). Concept map (Threat Modeling -> STRIDE/DFD -> Mitigations). Voter consensus: Completeness on NIST/STRIDE/sources. Generate flashcards per schema: Balance layers/objectives. MCQs with distractors (plausible errors). Each card JSON: {'type': 'MCQ/Definition/etc.', 'bloom_level': 'REMEMBER/etc.', 'layer': 1-4, 'front': '...', 'back': {'answer': '...', 'explanation': '...', 'distractors_explained': '...', 'source': '...'}}. Ensure active learning tie-ins (e.g., scenario from problem-solving). Output as numbered list of JSON objects.
